reviewText:
What once was a very impressive little title has now turned into one of the biggest franchises for Square Enix and a Cult Favorite among the fans, so let's see how it all began shall we ?

In Just Cause we play as Rico Rodriguez. He is an agent sent in to the island San Esperito. Our mission is to kill a dictator Mendoza and free the island from his reign.

Back when this game came out I found it quite impressive. The Island is massive, but it doesn't matter cause there is nothing to see there. All of it is just a big jungle which all of it looks the same. There are small villages which act as outposts and you can clear them out.  The city is uninspiring and there's nothing to do there.

The gameplay is by far the weakest third person shooter I have ever seen. The shooting feels clunky and sometimes my shots don't even connect with the enemies, not to mention most guns are weak as hell, and the better weapons have low ammo counts.

The graphics (apart from the CGI cut scenes) are still great. The lush island is awesome and getting a boat and going through the rivers is really fun, but as stated before there's nothing to see, but it's still fun.

The driving controls are some of the worst driving controls I have ever seen, they even top the driving controls in Watch Dogs. Since unlike in Just Cause 2 you can't travel with the grappling hook, so most of the time you will need to use vehicles.

The game also has side quests, but most of them are boring as hell and you can grind them since they never end. So if you want something more with the game after you're done you can do the mundane side quests.

The game took me 6 hours to finish, once the game is finished you can explore the island, but as stated before there's nothing to do there.

The game also has a major spike in difficulty in the final missions, so be prepared to be ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off.

Overall even though the game didn't age well, it's still fun to play for a bit, but it's the weakest in the series. In the end I will give this a positive review, but I still suggest playing Just Cause 2 instead.

Final Rating:
6/10 - Okay

Vehicles include cars, motorcycles, boats, helicopters and planes, all of these types can come armed with machineguns and/or rockets, and all of them useful: sail, since you're in an island paradise, and going across water may be the shortest distance between two points; helicopter flight is easily the most flexible way to travel, because of mountains and sea; and planes are by far the fastest way to travel far. Control is great, no matter what you travel by. Fairly challenging. Limits on ammo and weapon carry capacity(two pistols, two types of C4, and another two guns - choose carefully between SMGs, assault and sniper rifles, RPGs and a grenade launcher) ensure that you are careful in shootouts. A fun arcade game.

Cons: Very clearly rushed, with glitches and bugs. Nothing to do once you've completed the short story and liberated all enemy zones and/or completed a certain number of the uninspired, crushingly inconsequential and repetitive side-missions. Characters are bland, and there's little to the story, meaning there's almost no meat" to what's going on(the fun stuff is all in the game-play). reviewText:
This review is for the game ''Just Cause'',an open world third-person shooter video game,developed by the video game company Avalanche Studios.
The game was published by Eidos Interactive and released in Semptember 22 on 2006(in Europe).
The game can be run through Microsoft Windows,Playstation 2,Xbox and Xbox 360.
The game uses the Avalanche Engine with Havok physics.

Genre(s):Action-Adventure
Mode(s):Single-player
Distribution:Optical Disc,download

Plot
You take control of Rico Rodriguez,an agent for an unkown organization called the Agency,
who is being dropped to a tropical island(called San Esperito)by the order of the commanding
officer Tom Sheldon in order to help overthrow San Esperito's dictator,Salvador Mendoza,
whom the Agency thinks to be in possession of nuclear weaponry.

Soon after your arrival you rendezvouses with Tom Sheldon and his partner Maria Kane who ally
themselves(as well as you) with a Guerrilla group starting a rebellion against the dictator and
the Rioja drug cartel(even though they are enemies with the government).Eventually Rico will have to face
the corrupt officials(Black Hand mercenaries)  and the Montano cartel(Rioja's drug cartel enemy).

Lastly,Tom Sheldon discovers that Mendoza has in fact nuclear weapons and with San Esperito politically unstable the president is forced to retreat to his private island.He makes a last attempt to escape after he is being discovered by Rico but the agent risks his life and gets into a flying plane after a ridiculous stunt,kills the Black Hand officials and destroys the President once and for all.

Gameplay

The game incorporates basic third-person shooter elements in a huge driving open world environment to interact in.
You are capable of walking,swimming,jumping and use a wide variety of vehicles including:cars,boats,aircrafts and
motorcycles.Rico can also perform stunds,choose when to open his parachute(of course while in air) and use the
exceptionally useful Protec Grappler G3 which is a high-powered magnet harpoon device and can stick to metal
surfaces.That allows Rico to engage in a wide variety of stuntsand immobilize vehicles as well as many other things.

Recap
I find this game awfully boring and repetitive.Story missions are dull and uninspiring.Side missions given by the Rioja
drug cartel are even worse.The graphics are exceptionally bad even for a 2006 game.And to make things worse
bugs and glitches swarm about the game making it almost unplayable.Settlement liberations not challenging and alike(Kill some soldiers,destroy the roadblocks,repeat again 2 times and the capture the flag).Cliche catchphrases are pretty lame too.

Q:If that's the case why bother buying or even playing the game?

A:That is the video game developer's first attempt into the gaming industry.Of course there would be some mistakes.
You should also take into account that it was rushed to the market for unkown reasons at least to me.Personally I
played the game and completely finished it before getting to play Just Cause 2 which was released four years later.

I recommend this game only if you are a completionist like me and want to explore everything that involves a gaming
series like the Just Cause series.

P.S Support the developers!

reviewText:
I really want to recommend this game, but there are more negatives than positive. Almost everything has a problem with it.

Just Cause is the first game in the Just Cause series, made by Eidos Studios. After a few years, Square Enix took the developing rights of JC and made Just Cause 2, a HUGE improvement to the first one.

Let's start off with the graphics. They O.K for 2006, but it could've definetely been improved. Rico Rodriguez, the game's main protagionist, has the most bland outfit ever. (All black. Is he Goth or something?) The cutscenes look WAY better than the actual game, but seeing what exactly the cutscenes look, I'd stick with the normal graphics. Another thing that threw me off is that they have 1280 x 600 and 1600 x 1200, but no 1366 x 768. Why not? Surely there would've been 1336 x 768 back then. Not a big problem, but a little annoying.

Next, the story. Basic. You are Rico Rodriguez, Agency agent. You must fight the evil forces of the president of San Esperito, Salvador Mendoza by blowing up stuff, helping a guerilla army fight the corrupt police and helping Yellow drug cartel fight Purple drug cartel. That's kinda it. Or that's all I know, for now. I haven't finished the game yet, nor do I have any intention of. This is more simple than your regular oh-no-guy-killed-family-must-kill-all-living-things movie. Like I said, I haven't finished the game yet, but I wished the story had more depth. More complexity.

The combat. Oh sweet Jesus. Where to start? If you hit a car, member, or other vehicle of the police or Purple drug cartel, THEY WILL BE UP YOUR ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•! They will send loads of cars and trucks and helicopters after you. It's fun, until you get out of your flaming car and either get killed by the explosion or the flurry of bullets. If you DO happen to survive, you can shoot 'em. But, you might be outnumbered. There are a lot of weapons, and utilizing them is your #1 priority. The problem is, when you die, you lose ALL your weapons, except for your (crappy) grappling hook and your dual pistols, which conviently have infinite ammo. And your safehouses, the places you spawn at, have certain weapons. For example, one safe house has a bazooka and shotgun, but another one has a machine gun and a pistol. So if you want a big arsenal, you're gonna cross the whole map building it up, only to die to that stray missile from that Apache.

And now, the enemies. There are the police, who fight the guerillas occasionaly and mostly lose. Sometimes, if you're lucky, you might see a guerilla helicopter shoot at a police car or van and explode in a unimpressive explosion. There are also liberations, which involves storming a town with other guerilla soldiers while fighting police and SWAT and a po-po heli. There are also roadblocks, depending on the size of the town. Little ones, roadblocks. Big ones, a swarm of army soldiers. Also fighting with you is the Yellow drug cartel, who is fighting Purple drug cartel. There are also liberations here, but you're fighting Purple drug cartel instead of police. The missions are as hard as hell sometimes, like one where you have to destroy coca fields. When I completed that objective and went to a bar to complete it, I was running away on some baggage carrier modified to spray chemicals while Purple drug cartel and police are shooting me from every direction. About 400 meters from my destination, I had to leg it, chased by numerous Purple drug cartel and police bikes and vans and a helicopter. I reached the bar just in time, when I only had a little line of health.

CONCLUSION: This game definetly has its good features, like adrenaline-pumped moments and blowing up stuff, but it is light, compared to the bad features. This game felt like it was an idea, not completed or polished. I definitely recommend the second JC, which is an actual game instead of an experiment like this game.

FINAL SCORE: 4/10

reviewText:
Inspired by free-roaming action games such as Grand Theft Auto and Far Cry, Just Cause drops you (literally, out of an aeroplane) onto a tropical island that's in need of a little regime change.
With silent backing from the CIA, your character Rico has gadgets, guns and an endless supply of disposable vehicles with which to wreak havoc.
Rico also has the infinite use of a parachute that pops out and packs itself away in the blink of an eye. All you need do is find a lofty point from which to leap and you can drift over villages, motorways and wide channels of water.
Fire your grappling gun and Rico will hook onto passing cars or helicopters for a little paragliding - handy when you need an altitude advantage over your opponents or want to catch up on a crook.
However, even with this unique mode of transport, getting around is a slow and sometimes tedious affair. Reaching each new mission marker can sometimes mean at least five minutes of travel time.
As with GTA, the action here involves hectic car chases, shootouts with the corrupt local officials and various seek-and-destroy missions in which you can enjoy the spectacle of big things blowing up. Typically, the player can hijack cars, bikes, boats and even helicopters, as well as kill time on various side missions that involve collecting hidden packages or performing hitman duties.
Sloppy vehicle handling, some bugs in the design of the missions and the endless travel means it doesn't hit the same high notes as GTA and others, but the mindless action is still good dumb fun.
An ambitious action affair that sometimes gets a little lost in the wilderness.

reviewText:
Being the first game in the Just Cause series, you shouldn't expect it to be perfect, because it's not. But for all it's flaws, it's glorious because of how massive in scope and epicness it is.

Something like ~365 sq miles, the world is your playground, and not because of the sidequests, which are many yet repetitive; i.e; help the guerillas take over political territory, and help the Rioja family expand and defeat the other competing/mafia type family. The side quests are many and they do have their advantages when advancing through the game for opening safe houses and extra weapons, but are otherwise unnecessary.

No, the world is your playground because of how ridiculous it is. Police everywhere, villages are spread out, mountains, mountains, and mountains are all over with hills, rivers, cliffs, etc. The only thing that kept the diverse landscape vague was the color, which is pretty much all green. There's grass everywhere, you can't go anywhere without seeing grass unless you drive a boat out to sea.

A game released in 2006, this could have easily been on all next gen systems, but you can tell Avalanche had focused with the Xbox and PC while also trying to transition to 360, as the models are pretty good, but the textures are certainly at the end of the Xbox and PS2 era.

As for travel, you get planes, helicopters, tanks, cars, trucks, etc. There's an infinite amount of vehicles at your disposal. Again, you'll have to advance the sidequests to unlock some of the cool ones, but completely unnecessary.

The plot is okay. It's nothing special, run and gun doing espionage esq type missions, sort of like James Bond espionage, but less stealthy. You are Rico and are sent by the Agency to help rid the country island of San Esperito of its corrupt El Presidente and followers. It's fun, but rather short, you can probably beat it in 4 or 5 hours, depending on the difficulty and amount of time you spend in between missions.

8.3/10

And at the first mission, I had to fight through a bridge guarded by cops, but I only just stopped my vehicle just in front of the security block and the cops started shooting (I haven't even done anything wrong yet). And too many instances of r3tarded-looking AI.

Fast travel is absolutely necessary to get just about anywhere as the map is truly enormous and for the most part empty.

If you were wanting to get this game for the story so you could go into the sequels, I would give this game a pass. The story consists (no spoilers) of nothing more than eliminating a dictator and a drug cartel and the side characters are mildly funny but shallow.

reviewText:
If you love Just Cause 2 then you have to play the original.
Whilst JC2 is all about causing as much chaos as possible, JC1 is all about the story and the missons.

The game still features a massive map in which you are free to do as you wish, and also includes lots of cars, aircraft, boats etc.
Whilst you aren't exploring the massive island, you'll be liberating towns from the government, doing side missions such as assisnating key government figres, or even simple things like collecting cars or drug deals.

JC1 feels a lot like earlier Grand Theft Auto games, You have a safehouse where you can store weapons and cars etc.
And whilst this game does feature a paracehute, and a grapple gun, yes a gun, you have to equip it to use it.
You shouldn't count on it to get you around.

Overall the game is very enjoyable, despite showing its age in the graphics department the fun still remains.

So, if you enjoy Just Cause 2 and maybe you are interested in seeing where JC2 came from, Maybe you want to go back for the story, Or maybe you ae just looking for another game to add to your Steam Libary, I would absoloutely recommend this.

Even better if you can get it in a steam sale ;)

reviewText:
I bought this game to tide myself over until I could muster enough money to buy a machine that could run Just Cause 2 at any decent frame rate, and I definitely can't say I regret my purchase.

For a 2006 title it has a huge sandbox. Even some recent  titles struggle to compare- it is visually stunning; the  screenshots on the store page don't do it justice, on higher graphical settings it feels like you're on holiday, the most danderous holiday you'll have. Although saying that, there is very little variation from mountainous forest to tropical beach,and the cities are not quite GTA V's los santos. The in game music is very nice, I could listen for hours. It captures the Caribbean setting perfectly, in my opinion.

It never won't be fun to fly a plane close enough to the ground to see  the foliage and then hastily disembarking to watch the carnage unfold, and this game, for it's time, gives a decent variety of planes, helicopters, cars, boats, guns, and explosives to play with. The downside being, of course, that many such toys are locked away untill you've completed dismayingly similar missions numerous times. Which may have been more interesting for much longer had the hostile NPCs been given any form of a competent AI, and the friendly AI seems to be all too intrigued about what's coming out the end of your gun, though I shouldnt complain about AI from that era.

Also I can't tell if any of the guns do more or less damage. A stats screen wouldnt have gone amiss, if the different gun shapes aren't purely for aesthetics. As a result the side missions are an absolute chore and still necessary to get anything large and flammable. From the little Just Cause 2 I've been able to play, the grapple hook and parachute system is much more fluid, but don't get me wrong, the system in the original works fine.

The animations in the game such as Rico's running looks pretty dodgy and can be pretty amusing at first, but is distracting from there on out. The story isn't brilliant, but who's playing games of this genre in place of a bedtime read? The greatest annoyance I have with this game are the NPC voices; the developers seemed content to hire just two voice actors for the entire civilan population, though, it's nothing a low flying plane can't fix.

All in all, Just Cause is definitely worth your time, whether you dont yet have the computing power to run Just Cause 2, just enjoy the genre because this is a great game in it's own right, or have already completed the Just Cause 2 and want to experience it's roots, and for under ¬£5 is a bargain. If you can get it on sale, all the better. however if it's between Just Cause and it's sequal, Just Cause 2 would be a better use of your cash.

reviewText:
While the second game is obviously superior, there are a few things that the first does better.

- Everything from the shooting to the flying is faster and more responsive, if a bit unrealistic. For example, stunt jumps aren't necessarily affected by gravity, planes never stall, and helicopter propellor blades can touch almost anything without affecting control.
- The entire game can be taken at one's own pace, with side missions free to perform at the player's choosing.
- The world has one central theme, Caribbean jungle, as opposed to every type of biome crammed into one country. This makes the locations memorable by relying on clever geography and buidling placement, instead of the false illusion of a major change of global locale. Plus, it's just pretty to look at, most of the time.

That being said, the game isn't perfect. There are plenty of bugs to look out for, both fun and bad. I've gotten trapped inside garages simply by respawning. I've driven a motorcycle so fast that I crashed into a person's house and became stuck inside. All of those incidents required me to load a previous save. Then there are the police who never EVER shut up, and the idiotic AI that deems it fit to pilot a helicopter into the side of a mountain or skyscraper. There's a monster truck with hollow tires. There are also the occasional missing or misapplied textures.

Yet, on the other hand, I come back and find new bugs, or perhaps just oversights, every time I play. Rico is capable or rocket-jumping with the correct equipment, something I never thought I would see outside of FPS. He can kill himself with a heavy drop. Hell, once I took down a passing helicopter simply by requesting a vehicle at the right time. I've toyed around with the camera by grappling onto boats outside of the game's invisible ocean walls. It's even possible to do some sweet tricks by letting the cannon on a tank touch an immovable object. It's not often I see a big vehicle like that spinning and flipping that quickly.

All in all, it's a good sandbox game, but don't expect a lot of depth.

reviewText:
Just Cause is a 3rd person shooter with a forgivably cheese ball story and a lot of cool ideas. You play as Rico Rodriguez, a suave secret agent type on a mission to overthrow the dictator of the Caribbean island San Esperito. There's a giant open world, a set of factions warring against the currently established government, a grappling hook that can shoot you towards cars/boats/planes/etc, and a parachute you can pull anytime your high enough off the ground. Unfortunately, it is in the execution of these ideas that the game starts to fall apart.

To start, the world of San Esperito is truly massive and pretty impressive for such an old game (2006). This seems great until you realize that it consists mostly of long stretches of dense forests and tall mountains that make traversing it a huge pain. The various planes, jets, helicopters, and boats all do a well enough job at getting you from point A to point B, heck even jumping off a high mountain and gliding with your parachute is a pretty quick way to get around, but running on the other hand is completely off the table and the ground vehicles are arguably just as bad of an option with crazy amounts of oversteer making driving less of a convenience and more of a challenge.

San Esperito is also populated with a few cities, some villages, and a couple of army bases. These all start off as government/cartel controlled but can be taken over. Just Cause is simply a bad port of a relatively old and mediocre game.  The controls are awful; even the AI seems to have trouble driving.  The story is copy-paste: military badass defeats evil dictator and his lackeys.  The gameplay is boring and unbalanced.  Huge stretches of terrain separate virtually identical 'liberations' that have no impact on the story.  Enemies can deliver small scratches or one-hit kills.  There are no difficulty settings.  As previously mentioned, the game is a bad port: no resolution support, no controller support, and a number of bugs.

As the game's cast may put it, Just Cause is a 'gigundo' mess.

6/10

reviewText:
Short Review:
The game is dated and its age clearly shows. When I first got the game, the user reviews were mostly positive. Now it's mixed, so you can probably tell from that too.

Full Review:
- Gameplay & Graphics
While the scenes in the video look nice, playing it in 2014 with a 1680 x 1050 resolution and later in 2015 with a 1920 x 1080 resolution makes me feel like crying. If you force the game to full screen, it's pixelated, else it's small. I could adjust my default screen resolution to suit the game, but this simply reinforces that the game is outdated. It may be good in 2006, but certainly not now. The controls are your typical WASD and mouse interaction, while for the gameplay itself, I did not fully explore the game so I cannot offer a full storyline review. However, from my early stages in the game, it takes way too long to travel from one point to another with little to offer. While Far Cry also requires you to walk a long distance, at least you get to hunt some game. Not in Just Cause 1. It's just holding W and hoping someday, you get there.

- Audio
The music and sound effects are pretty average in my opinion. I'm not a fan of it, but taste is subjective.

- Verdict
Don't buy it, even it's for a really cheap 90% discount. Unless you're using an older and smaller computer, you've played it before and you want to play it again. In that case, follow your desire.

reviewText:
Honestly it felt like a GTA game, but with a story more like Mercenaries and less gangster related with more stuff getting blown up. The island was big and there were plenty of items to collect, but the world itself still felt a bit empty. Being able to paratroop a vehicle anywhere was really neat, although I didn't discover I could do that until the latter half of the game. The main missions became considerably easier with some of Rico's custom vehicles. The hook shot system was a bit rough, hooking onto moving objects rarely worked out like I had intended it to but it was fun to experiment with.

Sadly it was impossible to get a controller to work with the game properly, and the advanced settings were a bit lacking, especially in the resolution department. A lot of the same sounds got reused very often which got a bit annoying after a while.

Although there were plenty of side quests scattered around the map they were only interesting really if you wanted to unlock the particular item/weapon that was at the end of the faction points system. Being able to jump across the map with the jet from the menu made buying safe houses kind of pointless. Still the game was definitely fun even if it was rather similar to a GTA game of the same caliber. While it was not very impressive after playing JC2 or a more recent GTA game I'm sure when it came out it must have been more entertaining when there weren't many games like it on the market.  It is nice if you want to see where Rico and the Just Cause series got their roots from. It hasn't aged very well though.

reviewText:
'Just Cause' is the story of Che Guevara, an Argentine Marxist revolutionary, physician, author, guerrilla leader, diplomat, and military theorist. A major figure of the Cuban Revolution, his stylized visage has become a ubiquitous countercultural symbol of rebellion and global insignia in popular culture.

Playing Che as a young medical student, you travel throughout South America and become radicalized by the poverty, hunger, and disease that you witness. Most of this part of the game consists of quicktime events punctuated by scenes of you jogging down corridors and along dusty streets, but the tight controls more than make up for any boredom you might feel.
Your burgeoning desire to help overturn what you see as the capitalist exploitation of Latin America by the United States prompts your involvement in Guatemala's social reforms under President Jacobo √Årbenz, and at this point in the game you join one of three factions which you will stay as for the rest of the game. In my playthrough I joined the 'Reapers' which was more of a fetch-quest based plot but I really like these because I'm a masochist.
The president's eventual CIA-assisted overthrow at the behest of the United Fruit Company solidifies your political ideology and you can start earning perks that upgrade Che based on three trees - Ideology, Philosophy and Taxation Schemes. Ideology allows you to increase Che's intelligence making things like lockpicking and sneaking easier. Philosophy makes people dislike Che more but you're able to find things like hidden doors and alternative roads thanks to 'thinking outside of the box'. Taxation Schemes are probably the most useful tree and are fairly self-explanatory.
Later, in Mexico City, you meet Ra√∫l and Fidel Castro, join their 26th of July Movement, and sail to Cuba aboard the yacht, Granma, with the intention of overthrowing U.S.-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. The yacht becomes a hub for you and your men and from here you can use an extensive crafting system to make new weapons. Whilst the other NPCs are in your party you can outfit them with weapons and skills just as you can for Che. The AI is a little patchy in places but for the most part works fine.
You soon rise to prominence among the insurgents, get promoted to second-in-command, and play a pivotal role in the victorious two-year guerrilla campaign that is set on deposing the Batista regime. At this point the game moves to a top-down perspective ala Sim City, and most of the gameplay from now on is based around maps of military strategies and other boring stuff.

I guess it's alright.

reviewText:
'Just Cause' is the story of Che Guevara, an Argentine Marxist revolutionary, physician, author, guerrilla leader, diplomat, and military theorist. A major figure of the Cuban Revolution, his stylized visage has become a ubiquitous countercultural symbol of rebellion and global insignia in popular culture.

Playing Che as a young medical student, you travel throughout South America and become radicalized by the poverty, hunger, and disease that you witness. Most of this part of the game consists of quicktime events punctuated by scenes of you jogging down corridors and along dusty streets, but the tight controls more than make up for any boredom you might feel.
Your burgeoning desire to help overturn what you see as the capitalist exploitation of Latin America by the United States prompts your involvement in Guatemala's social reforms under President Jacobo √Årbenz, and at this point in the game you join one of three factions which you will stay as for the rest of the game. In my playthrough I joined the 'Reapers' which was more of a fetch-quest based plot but I really like these because I'm a masochist.
The president's eventual CIA-assisted overthrow at the behest of the United Fruit Company solidifies your political ideology and you can start earning perks that upgrade Che based on three trees - Ideology, Philosophy and Taxation Schemes. Ideology allows you to increase Che's intelligence making things like lockpicking and sneaking easier. Philosophy makes people dislike Che more but you're able to find things like hidden doors and alternative roads thanks to 'thinking outside of the box'. Taxation Schemes are probably the most useful tree and are fairly self-explanatory.
Later, in Mexico City, you meet Ra√∫l and Fidel Castro, join their 26th of July Movement, and sail to Cuba aboard the yacht, Granma, with the intention of overthrowing U.S.-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. The yacht becomes a hub for you and your men and from here you can use an extensive crafting system to make new weapons. Whilst the other NPCs are in your party you can outfit them with weapons and skills just as you can for Che. The AI is a little patchy in places but for the most part works fine.
You soon rise to prominence among the insurgents, get promoted to second-in-command, and play a pivotal role in the victorious two-year guerrilla campaign that is set on deposing the Batista regime. At this point the game moves to a top-down perspective ala Sim City, and most of the gameplay from now on is based around maps of military strategies and other boring stuff.

I guess it's alright.

The game is dated and its age clearly shows. When I first got the game, the user reviews were mostly positive. Now it's mixed, so you can probably tell from that too.

Full Review:
- Gameplay & Graphics
While the scenes in the video look nice, playing it in 2014 with a 1680 x 1050 resolution and later in 2015 with a 1920 x 1080 resolution makes me feel like crying. If you force the game to full screen, it's pixelated, else it's small. I could adjust my default screen resolution to suit the game, but this simply reinforces that the game is outdated. The controls are your typical WASD and mouse interaction, while for the gameplay itself, I did not fully explore the game so I cannot offer a full storyline review. The music and sound effects are pretty average in my opinion. I'm not a fan of it, but taste is subjective.

- Verdict
Don't buy it, even it's for a really cheap 90% discount. Unless you're using an older and smaller computer, you've played it before and you want to play it again. In that case, follow your desire.

reviewText:
Got this and it's sequel in a bundle a long time ago, figured it was time to check them out now that #3 has dropped and looks fun.

Observations - not going pro/con as in this case I feel that's a bit subjective:
- Game shows it's age (2006) by not supporting bigger resolutions.
- Map is surprisingly HUGE and not in a good way really. It takes forever to get places, even with a chopper or really fast boat
- Half the time I feel like Superman, the other I'm getting run over and killed by my supporting AI
- Audio is annoying, music from certain areas sometimes sticks with you as you move about
- Random NPC phrases get extremely repetative and annoying in areas of population
- Unlimited pistol ammo, but very limited assult/SMG/etc ammo
- Unlike the Far Cry series which I can in some ways compare this to, the green forrest aren't at all worth visiting are are very boring with zero variety
- Not a lot is explained, each mission will have details but you have to open the menu, then open mission info to learn details
- Voice acting from the very dated CGI cuts scenes is poor, but not terrible for the period
- Buggy with lots of pop-in/drop-out artifacts, mainly cars and enemies. I called in a truck, drove it 200 feet and it died, won't move. Figured ok, got another ride, quit the game later, saving, played again after a while, called in truck, it's still dead, really?
- Map is SO big and it takes you SO long to traverse it on foot that you need vehicles or use the fast travel/agency pick-up system, otherwise it gets BORING wandering around pretty quick.
- Side missions include checkpoint races, fetch quests and kill quests. They never end, so you can do them over and over and that's annoying for completionists like myself. Worse you won't know which you've already done and it's hard to see the benefits until you visit a safehouse.
- Driving physics/controls are comically poor, if you get a flat rear tire on a rear drive vehicle enjoy unbarable oversteer, overall every land/sea vehicle has felt very floaty, getting airborn often gives a lame slow-mo shot, crashing off a cliff and getting the car to roll leads to funny physics.
- The chopper controls are decent, but if you jump out and depoly your parachute it's really hard to gauge how high up your are, so don't let go until you land.

I can see the roots of some cool gameplay elements and features that I suspect have helped define this franchise. However if you make this your first game in the series be preparred to have frustrations. So far for me the frustrations haven't led to rage quits or anything and the difficulty so far has been reasonable - EDIT: essentially rage quit the last time, frustrating difficulty, uninstalling game, updating this review, moving on.

Recommend?
EDIT: I had to change this review. Simply can't recommend this game, it's ENTIRELY TOO HUGE, it takes forever to traverse even with a chopper, forget a car as you almost 100% have to stay on the roads, and F walking, it takes FOREVER - I ended up setting something on my E key to keep moving forward when boringly trying to get somewhere.
Bugs - pull a guy out of a ride and watch his door go flying, get into a APV, get bumped and watch your several ton armored vehicle roll, even fly around, don't walk near a road or get insta-killed by being run over, revive at a safe house only to land inside the structure, stuck.
Difficulty ramped up a TON after I gained control of approximately 50% of the map. When it takes you 5 mins to get from a spawn point/safe house via chopper to your takeover area only to have your mission ramp to level 5 (top threat level) within 30 seconds and have rockets fired at you from God only knows where and die. Then take another 5 mins to get back there to get closer but still die - it's no longer fun and therefore not worth the time, I have way too many other games that I know are better waiting, including hopefully a greatly improved Just Cause 2.

My progress:
My first review was after 7.4 hours in, this update is after over 20 hours. I think I made it around 40-45% through the story missions and I collected around 85% of the pickups while liberating right around 50+% of the map, done several side quests too getting my militia and gang supports up pretty high. I struggled to put aside my completionish mentality and focus on the story, but avoided extra side missons, instead just aiming to liberate all of the locations. After having the difficulty ramp up so much in the last few missions/liberation attempts I just can't see wasting anymore time trying to do really anything else. I tried, but the game defeated me...

reviewText:
I mainly played this, just to see how Just Cause 2 got it's roots. I can see that the roots for Just Cause 2 were well fertilized, because Just Cause OG is sh**!

Well, okay, to be fair Just Cause 1 is a lot better than a lot of other games. It feels sort of like playing Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, with slightly less clunkier controls and slightly better graphics. However, the game has some severe problems with both narrative and gameplay that cause it to just truly suffer.

My biggest qualms with the gameplay is how easily cheated it can be. The loading screens advertize all the cool weapons and vehicles you could unlock by freeing more cities, but I got pretty much all the best gear by the end only by playing the regular story missions. And the two staples of the game- the parachute and grappling hook- both absolutely suck in this game. For one, the grappling hook is very selective. It will latch onto any vehicle or person you aim it at, but not trees, rocks, or land- which renders it basically pointless. Plus, parachuting to cars or helicopters is rubbish, since you have to reel yourself close enough to the vehicle for it to work. And Scorpio obviously has some sort of strange disease in his arms, causing them to only aim his grappling hook forward. Once a helicopter flies behind you while you reel it in, you're done. And trying to get onto cars is a massive pain, since you gradually sink to the ground (even if the car is driving at top speed).

The gameplay also takes its biggest dip during the end mission. The game builds up all this variety and open mission play-style, and the end mission completely negates that. You fly in on a helicopter but can't fly it to the island. Cars attract helicopter missiles. And missiles blasting your body cause you to bounce back and forth like a pinball, constantly taking damage. And damage can only be healed by the random health-pack spawning out of dead enemies, which is very uncommon.

The cutscenes are also really weird to watch. The animation studio chose some very strange character models (and some even worse voice actors), and the scenes that explain situations come off as weird, in the sense that characters say sentences in completely off tones, or come off as weird since the characters themselve look very inhuman. In fact, Just Cause has a very toy-ish feel. The cars look like Hot Wheels cars, the characters look and animate like action figures. Even the samey world of San Esperito has a kid's-jungle-themed-toy-box appeal. The game just doesn't have a very fun or realistic draw to it.

I'm not saying everyone would hate this game. Between the wide variety of story missions, vast content, and world to explore- plenty of gamers will enjoy the original Just Cause. It just didn't impress me. I'm very picky with my sandbox games, and if you other 5% of Steam users that agree with my opinions are reading this, then you can be assured that Just Cause is not the game for you.
